title: Improving Few-Shot Learning through Multi-task Representation Learning Theory

sections.meta-learning algorithms:
Meta-learning algorithms considered below learn an optimal representation sequentially via the so-called episodic training strategy introduced by¬†[ref]51, instead of jointly minimizing the training error on a set of source tasks as done in MTR. Episodic training mimics the training process at the task scale with each task data being decomposed into a training set (support set SùëÜS) and a testing set (query set QùëÑQ). Recently,  showed that the episodic training setup used in meta-learning leads to a generalization bounds of O‚Äã(1T)ùëÇ1ùëáO(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}). This bound is independent of the task sample size n1subscriptùëõ1n_{1}, which could explain the success of this training strategy for FSC in the asymptotic limit.
However, unlike the results obtained by  studied in this paper, the lack of dependence on n1subscriptùëõ1n_{1} makes such a result uninsightful in practice as we are in a finite-sample size setting. This bound does not give information on other parameters to leverage when the task number cannot increase.
We now present two major families of meta-learning approaches below. Metric-based methods. These methods learn an embedding space in which feature vectors can be compared using a similarity function (usually a L2subscriptùêø2L_{2} distance or cosine similarity)  [ref]51 [ref]47  [ref]1  . They typically use a form of contrastive loss as their objective function, similarly to Neighborhood Component Analysis (NCA)¬† or Triplet Loss¬†. In this paper, we focus our analysis on the popular Prototypical Networks¬†[ref]47 (ProtoNet) that computes prototypes as the mean vector of support points belonging to the same class:

with SisubscriptùëÜùëñS_{i} the subset of support points belonging to class iùëñi.
ProtoNet¬†minimizes the negative log-probability of the true class iùëñi computed as the softmax over distances to prototypes ùêúisubscriptùêúùëñ{\mathbf{c}}_{i}: with dùëëd being a distance function used to measure similarity between points in the embedding space. Gradient-based methods. These methods learn through end-to-end or two-step optimization          where given a new task, the goal is to learn a model from the task‚Äôs training data specifically adapted for this task.
Maml¬† updates its parameters Œ∏ùúÉ\theta using an end-to-end optimization process to find the best initialization such that a new task can be learned quickly, i.e.¬†with few examples. More formally, given the loss ‚Ñìtsubscript‚Ñìùë°\ell_{t} for each task t‚àà[[T]]ùë°delimited-[]delimited-[]ùëát\in[[T]], Maml¬†minimizes the expected task loss after an inner loop or adaptation phase, computed by a few steps of gradient descent initialized at the model‚Äôs current parameters: with Œ∑ùúÇ\eta the distribution of the meta-training tasks and Œ±ùõº\alpha the learning rate for the adaptation phase. For simplicity, we take a single step of gradient update in this equation. In what follows, we establish our theoretical analysis for the popular methods ProtoNet¬†and Maml. We add their improved variations respectively called Infinite Mixture Prototypes¬†[ref]1 (IMP) and Meta-Curvature¬† (MC) in the experiments to validate our findings.
